description: Numbers n such that n divides sigma(n) - d(n).
comments: Or, numbers n such that sigma(n) = k*n + d(n) for some k.For most terms > 4, sigma(n) = 2*n + d(n), i.e., k=2. However, for the 12th term, k=3.If p = 2^m-(2m+1) is prime and n = 2^(m-1)*p then sigma(n) = 2*n+d(n), i.e., k=2 and n is in the sequence. 56, 7232, 30592, 36028789368553472, 9223371897268338688 and 29230032746618058364071726105239688547563879792624 are such terms of the sequence. - _Farideh Firoozbakht_, Aug 19 2013
links: Farideh Firoozbakht and M. F. Hasler, Variations on Euclid's formula for perfect numbers, Journal of Integer Sequences 13.3 (2010), 18 pp. Article ID 10.3.1.
formula: Numbers n such that A000203(n) (mod n) == A000005(n) or A054024(n)=A000005(n). - _Labos Elemer_, Apr 12 2002
author: _Robert G. Wilson v_, Jul 26 2000
